Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA Officer's decision on mixed questions of fact and law
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution in Sri Lanka as a failed asylum seeker; Tamil ethnicity; new evidence included father's letter and police report
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, redetermination of PRRA application
Court_Ruling: Judicial review granted; decision set aside and remanded for redetermination by a different officer
Defendant_Behavior: PRRA Officer excluded new evidence, applied incorrect legal test ('personalized risk'), failed to consider updated UNHCR Guidelines
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of persecution based on ethnicity and political opinion in Sri Lanka
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard for mixed questions of fact and law; correctness for pure legal questions
Assessment_Factor: Country conditions in Sri Lanka, treatment of Tamils, credibility of new evidence
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider new evidence and updated country condition reports during PRRA assessment
Credibility_Assessment: New evidence (father's letter, police report) not properly assessed
Evidence_Used: Father's letter, police report, UNHCR Guidelines on Sri Lanka
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act relating to PRRA and risk assessment
Application_Basis: Pre-removal risk assessment based on fear of persecution upon return to Sri Lanka
Evidence_Assessed: Limited; key documents excluded by PRRA Officer
Relief_Sought: Allowance of PRRA application, suspension of removal, protection from refoulement
Governing_Rule: PRRA officers must consider all relevant evidence and updated country conditions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Exclusion of new, credible evidence without justification
Outcome: Court overturned PRRA decision, ordered redetermination with inclusion of new evidence
Harm_Assessment: Risk of torture or persecution if returned to Sri Lanka due to Tamil identity and prior asylum claim
Cause_Description: Applicant faces heightened risk upon return to Sri Lanka as a Tamil and previous asylum seeker
Evidence_Handling: Improper exclusion of new evidence by PRRA Officer
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions requiring fair and comprehensive PRRA assessments
Evidence_Issues: Failure to admit and assess new documentary evidence
Residency_Compliance: Applicant was a permanent resident at time of application
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections governing PRRA
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of PRRA decisions
Evidence_Assessment: PRRA Officer did not adequately weigh new evidence or updated country reports
Decision_Rationale: Decision based on incorrect legal test and incomplete factual record
Evidentiary_Issues: Omission of critical evidence, lack of reference to current UNHCR guidelines
